title: Fasting as a potent antidote to obesity, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and the many symptoms of metabolic illness
content: Jason Fung shares his experiences utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients. We also have a great discussion on insulin resistance where Jason makes the case that we should actually think of hyperinsulinemia as the underlying problem. We also discuss the difference between time-restricted feeding, intermittent fasting, and dietary restriction (e.g., low-carb) and how they can be used to attack the root cause of T2D, metabolic syndrome, and obesity.

title: Utilizing Fasting to Treat Metabolic Disease
content: Jason Fung, a nephrologist and best-selling author, shares his experiences utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients.

title: Individualized approach to fasting for treating metabolic disease
content: Jason Fung shares his experiences utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients, and why being a doctor who specializes in kidney disease gives him a unique insight into early indications of metabolic disease. We also discuss the difference between time-restricted feeding, intermittent fasting, and dietary restriction (e.g., low-carb) and how they can be used to attack the root cause of T2D, metabolic syndrome, and obesity.

title: Insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia
content: We also have a great discussion on insulin resistance where Jason makes the case that we should actually think of hyperinsulinemia as the underlying problem. Insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and the overflow paradigm are discussed. How hyperinsulinemia (not insulin resistance) drives metabolic syndrome is also covered. Insulin and weight gain, and using fasting to empty the cells of glucose are also discussed.

title: Comparing scientific disciplines: Medicine and biology versus physics
content: Peter says what distinguishes Jason from others who like to speak about the benefits (and risks) of fasting is that Jason is on the front lines treating patients. Jason loves the approach to scientific progress in the realm of physics. He really looks up to Richard Feynman (as does Peter), Einstein, and Niels Bohr. In physics, if the theory doesn’t agree with experimental evidence, you have to throw out the theory. In medicine, bad theories tend to go round and round and round because they make sense, but nobody’s actually put them to the test. In the case of insulin resistance… “the way we think about insulin resistance is sort of totally wrong and that’s why we have the sort of mess that we have”

title: Biology vs. physics
content: Peter: “I’m generally suspect of people who have very, very strong points of view on things in biology or medicine who no longer interact with patients. Doesn’t mean that they’re wrong, but I’m generally suspect because of that.” Biology is harder than physics…. it’s just a lot messier. Peter: “Every time I think I’ve really got it figured out, I’ll always meet a patient who proves me wrong.”

title: The limitations of evidence-based medicine
content: In medicine, we have a super laborious process. We need evidence in order to move things forward. Whereas physics moves at “light speed” because it doesn’t demand the sort of evidence base. Evidence-based medicine is not a search for truth… it’s a search for consensus. This approach makes things move glacially. ⇒ For example, fasting… Five years ago, fasting was the dumbest thing you could do. But Jason treated hundreds and hundreds of patients, and the “results were amazing”

title: Nutrition in Evidence-Based Medicine
content: The best example of evidence-based medicine working is infectious disease. The treatment for most infections is remarkable, and the interventions are simple. However, most things in medicine are much more complicated than this. Evidence-informed medicine is probably a better way to think about it. People are very quick to say, for instance, “Well, you don’t have the evidence to support fasting for a patient with Type II Diabetes.” But… what’s the risk of NOT doing something? For example, people with Type 2 diabetes, the risk of NOT doing anything is huge compared to the risk of an intervention like fasting.

title: Early Signs of Metabolic Disease
content: Nephrology is a specialty of medicine that concerns itself with the kidneys. The last time we had a drug that actually slowed down progression of kidney disease was the ACE inhibitors in the 80s. More recently, we have the SGLT2 inhibitors for diabetic kidney disease. The kidney is an early warning indicator of disease either through high blood pressure or high glucose.

title: Kidneys and Nutrition
content: The kidneys are important organs in terms of longevity. Increased urine albumin excretion has a very strong correlation to heart disease. Peter has started to pay much closer attention to cystatin C, creatinine, along with microalbumin because he has begun to realize that the kidney, which often gets neglected, is one of the most important organs in terms of longevity. There are no symptoms of kidney disease, but it's easy to check in the urine, it's non-invasive, and anybody can do it.

title: Insulin Resistance and Nutrition
content: Insulin resistance is when insulin goes up, it allows glucose to go from the blood into the cells, but in the case of normal levels of insulin, and glucose can't make it into the cells, we call it insulin resistance. Insulin is a hormone. It acts on the insulin receptor, which is on the cell surface. The insulin receptor is like a gate. When you look at insulin and insulin receptors and see there is nothing wrong with them, the common thinking is that there must be something that's gumming up the system.

title: Insulin's functions and insulin resistance
content: Insulin has many functions, including letting glucose into the cell, de novo lipogenesis, and mitogenic effects. The body appears sensitive to insulin in a person with insulin resistance. For example, de novo lipogenesis works fine even in the face of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. Insulin is a growth factor and stimulates growth. Insulin has an effect on testosterone and PCOS. A common phenotype of insulin resistance is obesity. The problem is not insulin resistance per se, but hyperinsulinemia. The cell is already too full in a person with insulin resistance/T2D.

title: The suitcase analogy and high insulin environment
content: The suitcase analogy explains that using insulin to push more glucose into the cells is a problem because the cell is already too full in a person with insulin resistance/T2D. The solution is to empty that cell of glucose. Increasing insulin to deal with the excess glucose because of so-called “insulin resistance” actually supercharges the other effects of insulin on the body. It triggers the making of testosterone, PCOS, and the growth effects of insulin which has huge implications for cancer. Very insulin sensitive people have much higher rates in type 2 diabetes and obesity.

title: Why the common treatments for type 2 diabetes seem to make things worse
content: The common treatments for type 2 diabetes, such as sulfonylureas and exogenous insulin, try to shove more glucose into this already filled cell. This makes things worse because it increases the high insulin environment, which triggers the making of testosterone, PCOS, and the growth effects of insulin that have huge implications for cancer. Very insulin sensitive people have much higher rates in type 2 diabetes and obesity.

title: Drugs for T2D
content: The majority of drugs to treat T2D aren’t actually aimed at decreasing glucose, it’s more about increasing insulin, such as… Sulfonylureas, Exogenous insulin, DPP-4 inhibitors.

title: Why tight control of glucose with insulin doesn’t work long term
content: Trials like ACCORD, ADVANCE, and VADT all failed because they were working on this incorrect paradigm of insulin resistance (lock and key paradigm). This indicates that hyperinsulinemia itself is problematic.

title: SGLT2 inhibitors
content: The SGLT2s are a new class of drug which blocks the receptor on the kidneys where you’re actually absorbing the glucose, and you actually pee out the sugar. You do get some side effects: Urine infections, yeast infections, and for some reason, you get ketoacidosis, too. If you look at the trials, they’re actually quite consistent that you get a huge protective effects against kidney disease… Reduce the risk of kidney disease by about 25% and reduce the risk of heart disease. The reason it’s working is because it’s getting rid of the glucose as opposed to simply moving it around…“We’re emptying out that suitcase”.

title: Exercise
content: Peter points out that exercise increases a reservoir for glucose uptake, the muscle. The more one exercises, the more he/she could put away glucose into a muscle as glycogen. There is a benefit, for sure. But it is much less efficient than attacking the diet. The liver is really the key to type 2 diabetes, and you can’t exercise the liver.

title: Metabolic syndrome and insulin
content: Metabolic syndrome which is a constellation of five things: Increased blood glucose, Abdominal obesity, High triglycerides, Low HDL, High blood pressure.

title: Hyperinsulinemia and Metabolic Syndrome
content: The liver has too much glucose because of too much insulin so the liver is jam-packed. It wants to get rid of all this extra fat so it’s putting out tons of triglycerides (you get hypertriglyceridemia). And as triglycerides go up, HDL goes down. As you’re exporting out all of this fat, this fat goes into all kinds of places where it’s not supposed to go (the pancreas, the omentum fat, etc.) and you get abdominal obesity. Insulin also has an effect on blood pressure because insulin causes reabsorption of sodium at the site of the proximal tubule. The whole syndrome is not a syndrome of insulin resistance… It’s a syndrome of hyperinsulinemia.

title: The Solution to Hyperinsulinemia
content: If the problem is hyperinsulinemia, then the solution is completely obvious. Insulin is high… so we need to lower it. It’s no different than if your thyroid is too high, you want to lower it. In T2D, we know that insulin levels are high… so why did we think it would get better by giving more insulin? ⇒  We totally misunderstand the problem.

title: Insulin and Weight Gain
content: Studies (like the DCCT) show that insulin causes weight gain. People gained weight and eventually became hyperinsulinemic. Even T1D patients became hyperinsulinemic… You start out taking 15 units a day when you’re a kid. And then by the time you’re 45, you’re taking like 60 units a day. Why? You developed insulin resistance, and yet you had no insulin in your body in the first place 20 years ago. We thought that giving more insulin was good, but we didn’t realize that, hey, too much insulin is just as bad as too little insulin (or worse in this case).

title: The Negative Feedback Loop
content: ATP is going to block glycolysis which is going to block that glucose so you don’t overload the system. So now glucose can’t go in anymore. In other words, hyperinsulinemia, which is actually too much glucose, too much insulin, is going to feed back and not let the glucose into the cell which is why the glucose stays outside (in the blood), and you have this so-called insulin resistance. But the key is to empty out the cell of glucose. And how are you going to do that? ⇒ Low carbohydrate diets and intermittent fasting, says Jason.

title: Fasting to Empty the Cells of Glucose
content: “There is no more potent way to lower insulin than to fast.” —Peter Attia. Many people spend time arguing about whether low-fat or low-carb diets work best to lower insulin… but they seem to forget the infinitely more potent tool: eating nothing at all.

title: The two-step process of developing type 2 diabetes
content: The two-step process of developing type 2 diabetes is insulin resistance (or hyperinsulinemia) followed by beta-cell failure. The process takes about 10 years. Rising insulin resistance is met with hyperinsulinemia, which keeps the blood glucose normal, and it keeps it normal for a long time at the expense of hyperinsulinemia. Virtually all type two diabetics are reversible, and the youngest person ever to develop type two diabetes was a three-year-old girl. The only thing is that you only see beta-cell failure in this case of insulin resistance, and never anywhere else. These observations fit the overflow paradigm.

title: NAFLD and hyperinsulinemia: A vicious cycle
content: A very common patient presentation is hyperinsulinemia, with or without normal glucose levels, high ALT, and accumulation of fat in the liver. Treatment plans for this patient will resolve the NAFLD, normalize the ALT, and reduce hyperinsulinemia.

title: The fatty liver and pancreas are responsible for insulin resistance and beta failure
content: By eating nothing, you force your body to start using another fuel, and the first place it’s going to pull it out of is this fatty liver, which is causing a ton of cirrhosis and T2D because it’s actually part of the same problem. The fatty liver is responsible for the insulin resistance (hyperinsulinemia), and the fatty pancreas is responsible for the beta failure. They’re both manifestations of hyperinsulinemia.

title: Fructose and NAFLD
content: The fructose, which is metabolized in the liver, is causing fat accumulation specifically in the liver, and that is going to cause hyperinsulinemia, because the liver is full of all this excess fat, now you’re trying to shove all this glucose into this fatty liver cell and the liver is like, “no, I can’t take anymore so I’m going to be resistant to this” And as the liver gets resistant, the blood glucose goes up and then the body starts to have to make more insulin to control that situation. So, it seems like the arrow of causation goes both ways.

title: Protective Features and Symptoms of Diabetes
content: Jason says the following are not actually detrimental, they’re actually protective: Obesity, Insulin resistance, Fatty pancreas. Your body is actually trying to protect yourself against the root cause of the problem which is too much insulin, too much glucose.

title: Fatty Pancreas
content: Your pancreas makes a lot of insulin, makes a lot of insulin, makes a lot of insulin up onto a certain point until it’s all clogged up and it can’t make the insulin. So what happens? … You start to pee out all this sugar… you get polyuria, polydipsia, glycosuria, your body is actually trying to protect itself by peeing out all this sugar.

title: SGLT2s
content: They are effective because they attack the root cause.

title: Treatment with Insulin
content: When you actually give people more insulin, you actually keep all that glucose inside. And guess what? They gain weight.

title: The role of hyperinsulinemia in obesity and insulin resistance
content: According to Peter, hyperinsulinemia is the ultimate problem that causes obesity as a protective mechanism against too much glucose and too much insulin. A 1993 insulin study showed that hyperinsulinemia drives obesity rather than the other way around. Liposuction doesn’t reverse insulin resistance, and inflammation tends to go hand in hand with hyperinsulinemia in patients.

title: The effect of inflammation on weight loss
content: Anti-inflammatory medicine doesn’t seem to help people lose weight consistently, and Peter observed that hyperinsulinemic patients coupled with inflammation tend to NOT respond well to carbohydrate restriction and exercise and need fasting to move the needle.

title: The Role of Hormones in Obesity
content: Prednisone, which is used to suppress the immune system and decrease inflammation, actually tends to make people gain weight until they finish their course of the medication, and the weight comes back down. Other hormones, for example, are more obviously causal in terms of obesity. We know that cortisol for example has a huge impact on body fatness. Sex hormones have to play a role somewhere in there as well because there are women who develop gestational diabetes and their insulin, their diets, they don’t change. The difference is they got pregnant and that’s a difference in sex hormones. Looking at girls and boys at puberty for example… Yet girls who go through puberty have way more fat than boys (who get more muscle). So we know that there are other hormones that clearly have an impact, so it’s not just about insulin, but it’s about cortisol, it’s about sex hormones, and I think inflammation probably comes in there somewhere, but what to do about it and it’s a lot messier…too many moving parts.

title: Diseases of Too Much Growth
content: Jason says that the two top killers in America, CVD and cancer, are both diseases of too much growth. Growth in adults is generally bad. Once you reach adult size, your liver doesn’t grow, your kidney doesn’t grow, you shouldn’t be growing. Obesity, fatty liver, these are diseases of excess growth. If you have all this excess protein in your brain that’s blocking your signals, that’s Alzheimer’s disease. In the blood vessels, we know that there’s excessive growth. It’s not a matter of fat or cholesterol clogging your arteries like a pipe… those are a response to injury. It’s a response to injury, but you get excess proliferation of certain things (e.g., smooth muscle cells). Being obese, for example, it doesn’t give you cancer, but it certainly increases your risk of breast and colon cancer by a whole lot. There’s a very strong relationship between type 2 diabetes and breast cancer for example (due to the hyperinsulinemia). To me, those are all diseases of excessive growth and therefore you have to start looking at growth pathways . . . and all of these times that you can decrease nutrient sensors, that is decrease mTOR, decrease insulin, increase AMPK, you’re getting good effects for longevity.

title: Reducing Proliferation with Rapamycin, Nutrition, Exercise, Fasting, and Manipulating Hormones
content: Rapamycin has antiproliferative properties. Every chronic disease is some amount of hyperproliferation/hyper-growth. You have a drug here that in the most elegant way, in the least toxic way, in the most specific way, targets one of the most important regulators of growth (mTOR).

title: The Role of Hormones in Fat and Muscle Growth
content: Testosterone is anabolic to muscle and catabolic to fat. Insulin is anabolic to both muscle and fat. Bodybuilders use insulin because it is even more anabolic than testosterone.

title: Cortisol
content: Nutrition is one tool to manipulate hormones. The things that we care most about avoiding involve some measure of hyperproliferation and growth. There is a huge parallel between antibiotic resistance and insulin resistance. We treat insulin resistance with more insulin, which is what caused it in the first place, and then things get worse.

title: The paradigm of medicine did not change
content: We shifted from treating infectious diseases to chronic diseases but we never changed our paradigm of medicine. That’s totally the wrong thing because you don’t have a pill to decrease proliferation.

title: The 3 nutrient sensing pathways
content: The three pathways are Insulin, mTOR, and AMPK. Insulin responds to dietary carbohydrates and dietary proteins. mTOR responds mostly to dietary protein. AMPK actually measures the ATP, the AMPA, ATP ratio … so it actually doesn’t care what you eat, it just cares about the cellular energy availability.

title: Fasting
content: Fasting every so often has incredible benefits because you’re going to be able to affect those diseases of excessive growth. Fasting decreases insulin, decreases mTOR, and increases AMPK. All three things that you need to do in order to decrease proliferation so it’s the “best bang for your buck”.

title: Getting patients to fast
content: Before starting on longer fasts, Peter first starts his patients with the two easiest ways to help the patients escape the gravitational pull of eating pure garbage: 1) Time-restricted feeding, 2) Dietary restriction. Depending on how well those 2 approaches work, Peter may begin to encourage patients to incorporate longer fasting. Jason focuses heavily on the fasting from the start.

title: Frequency of Eating
content: When Jason decided to focus in on diet/nutrition with patients, he found that getting the patients to change the frequency of eating as opposed to what they’re actually eating, was much easier.

title: Fasting for T2D Patients
content: Jason wrote case report that was published in BMJ Case Reports. Three patients who had T2D for 20+ years using big doses on insulin. Put on a 24 hours of fasting three times a week (one-meal a day). They got off all their insulin between 5 and 18 days. They went from 20 years of diabetes to non diabetic, and have maintained it for the last six years.

title: Fasting vs Bariatric Surgery for T2D
content: Comparing bariatric surgery to fasting as a treatment for type 2 diabetes. Jason says you could probably get exactly the same results if you simply didn’t feed them for 14 days. In the cases that Jason has done this, the diabetes completely resolves. Jason refers to fasting as “medical bariatric”.

title: Overflow Paradigm
content: The overflow paradigm explains this. These 14 days fasts can reverse T2D because it is dropping insulin levels very low. After the first 24 hours, glycogen runs out. Your body is then going to have to metabolize fat for energy. The first place it’s going to start pulling fat out of is going to be the internal organs.

title: Fatty Liver and Pancreatic Function
content: The liver is going to be the first to lose fat. As this big fatty liver goes down, just like emptying your suitcase, the insulin resistance starts to melt away. Pancreatic fat starts to go down because your liver is not pumping out fat and dumping it in your pancreas. So you’re unclogging the pancreas, and you’re producing enough natural insulin that you don’t get the hyperglycemia anymore. Your glucose isn’t that high because now you’re at a stage where insulin production is going to go up. The insulin resistance is fatty liver. The beta cell failure is fatty pancreas. You’re getting rid of that first, and that’s why that diabetes goes away so quickly before you see significant weight loss.

title: Bypassing the duodenum and its effect on T2D
content: Bypassing the duodenum may improve T2D via bariatric surgery as the food they eat doesn’t get absorbed as much as they get fewer net calories from the same food.

title: Why people think that fasting is bad for you
content: Nutritional epidemiology studies are dangerous as they show correlation, not causation. For example, a recent publication suggested skipping breakfast increases the risk of cardiac mortality. Jason believes that everyone can fast, but people are told not to fast. The reason most people don’t fast is not because they can’t do it, but because people are telling them they shouldn’t fast.

title: Time-restricted feeding and intermittent fasting
content: Time-restricted feeding (TFR) is a 16 hour fast with an 8 hour feeding window (16:8) that can bring people back to baseline and can be a major improvement for people. Jason believes 16:8 fasting is more effective at weight loss than dietary restriction or calorie restriction largely because it is simply more practical/“easier”/less effort. Peter has seen mixed results on 16:8, but generally, the tighter his patient squeeze the window (18:6, 22:2), the more benefits they see. Intermittent fasting is when intermittently (periodically) fast for more than 24 hours.

title: Jason's protocols for intermittent fasting with patients
content: Jason individualizes the fasting plan by taking into account how severe the patient's condition is.

title: Nutrition and Fasting
content: Jason had a 40 year old patient with a non-healing diabetic foot ulcer for a year. Jason immediately started him on a full week of fasting followed by a 36 hour fast 3 times per week. His foot healed up in 3 weeks. Jason says that he just tells them up front, “This is gonna suck… you’re going to be hungry”. In a less severe case (i.e., a 40 year old with an A1c of 6.0), Jason would start them out slower and gradually move them up. Every patient is different. You can’t apply a stock plan to everyone. People respond differently.

title: Keys to a Successful Fast
content: Probably less than 50% (at least right off the bat) of Jason’s patients are willing to do a water-only fast for at least a period of three days. Fifty percent of people won’t fast for any period of time at all, “not even five hours” says Jason. And only about 20% of people will do a longer fast. “It’s not the physical side that actually gets them. It’s always the psychological side. The physical stuff is super easy to deal with. It’s the psychological part that’s really hard. . . That’s where we focus a lot of our attention, working on the psychological, how to set your environment up for success and coming up with different strategies for success and creating a supportive community that’s going to help your success.”

title: Keys to Overcoming the Difficulty of Fasting
content: A family and environment that that supports you is essential. If people are telling you to stop and that you’re crazy, you won’t get through it. Setting expectations regarding symptoms.

title: Potential Symptoms of Fasting
content: Potential symptoms include: It may be hard to sleep, Headaches, Cramps, Diarrhea (or constipation), Hunger

title: Understanding Temporary Pain for Powerful Results
content: Making sure they understand it is temporary pain for powerful results. Why patients warning them ahead of time helps because… They know what to do to relieve the symptoms (in cases you can do something i.e. headaches), They trust the doctor because the doctor told them something would happen and it did

title: Tips for Better Sleep During Fasting
content: Peter’s tip for help with sleep: Take phosphatidylserine with the fast in the evening. It calms down the adrenal glands. Example, an oral over-the-counter GABA. Unfortunately, it’s becoming harder to get centrally-penetrating GABA over the counter, but even just peripheral GABA will take down some of that sympathetic tone

title: Managing Electrolytes
content: Managing electrolytes. “The number of times that I’ve actually had to intervene or tell somebody to stop a fast because of electrolytes is zero.” Sodium. You can get some people who do get a bit sodium depleted. But if you’re otherwise healthy, your kidneys should never get to that state. Magnesium. A bit more difficult because a lot of type two diabetics are depleted of magnesium to start. Often recommend magnesium supplements especially if a patient is experiencing a lot of the cramps. For dizziness, Jason will recommend some bone broth (which is technically not a fast) but it’s got calories and amino acids that will help

title: Managing Hunger
content: Managing hunger. Feeling hunger is normal, just make sure you aren’t extraordinarily lethargic. Important note from Peter: Even seasoned fasters still get hungry. Personally for Peter, he feels quite hungry at some point in the day, every day. But… it’s never a feeling of hunger that is more profound than a regular day feeling “really hungry”. The seventh day of a fast is not a more profound hunger. It’s the anticipation of the hunger that becomes problematic

title: Muscle Loss During Fasting
content: Muscle loss during fasting, and why Jason isn’t worried. Nothing specifically, says Jason. But he’s generally treating a very sick population (i.e., not bodybuilders) who urgently need to lose weight and correct things. Protein loss or muscle loss? Jason says that the protein loss is often confused and called muscle loss

title: Excess Skin After Radical Weight Loss
content: No excess skin after radical weight loss. One of the things that’s very unusual about fasting for weight loss as opposed to weight loss for other things is that we don’t see the excess, flabby skin problems. Why? Skin is made of protein and connective tissue. When you do the intermittent fasting, you go through a period where you have gluconeogenesis and you’re breaking down protein. With massive weight loss from chronic calorie restriction, you are much more likely to see the large flaps of excess skin left over. But your body should get rid of it… so why doesn’t your body get rid of it? It’s because you never went through this period of gluconeogenesis, where you actually are breaking down protein

title: Gluconeogenesis and Fat Oxidation
content: During fasting, there's a period of gluconeogenesis followed by an increase in fat oxidation. A 1969 study by George Cahill showed this.

title: Excess Protein in Overweight Individuals
content: Overweight individuals have 20 to 50% more protein than regular individuals in the form of skin, muscle, connective tissue, and blood vessels. This excess protein needs to go. However, muscle loss is not a concern during fasting, as per Jason's experience with treating thousands of patients with type two diabetes.

title: Fasting and Chronic Diseases
content: Periodic fasting can reduce the odds of chronic diseases of hyperinsulinemia, such as heart disease, stroke, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, type two diabetes, and obesity. Fasting can potentially increase longevity and improve autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Gallstones and Fasting
content: Skipping breakfast may increase the risk of gallstones, but Jason doesn't see an increased risk in his practice. Low-fat diets can cause gallstones due to the bile sitting around with no fat to emulsify. Eating a higher fat diet after a low-fat diet can cause the bile to squeeze out and form stones.

title: Lower Fat Diet and Gallbladder Health
content: The lower fat diet may cause problems with gallbladder health because it reduces the intrahepatic flow. Eating zero fat may cause sludge to sit in the gallbladder, which is not a sensible approach to maintaining gallbladder health.
